tips.description: Sometimes used figuratively to indicate something is operating, e.g., a rumor running throu a crowd.
tips.example: A sense of excitement ran through the audience.

tips.description: It describes someone or something moving quickly on their feet.
tips.example: She could run faster than anyone on the team.

tips.description: It often appears as:
tips.example:
- Run fast
- Run away
- Run towards

tips.description: Sometimes used figuratively to indicate something is operating, e.g., a rumor running throu a crowd.
tips.example: A sense of excitement ran through the audience.

tips.description: Used when someone leaves without warning, causing surprise or concern.
tips.example: After the fight, Jake ran away without a word.

cards.description: To completely use up or consume all of a supply of something
cards.example: We've run out of milk, can you please buy some more?

tips.description: It often appears as:
tips.example:
- Jump off
- Jump out
- Jump over

cards.description: To move suddenly and quickly in a specific direction
cards.example: The cat jumped off the table when it heard the dog barking.

tips.description: Used for communal activities often held at celebrations or social gatherings.
tips.example: At weddings, guests often dance to celebrate.

tips.description: Can describe an activity done for personal joy, not just formal moves.
tips.example: Children dance happily to their favorite songs.

tips.description: It often appears as:
tips.example:
- Dance to music
- Dance with someone
- Dance around

cards.description: To move your body in a way that goes with the rhythm and style of music that is being played
cards.example: She loves to dance salsa music

tips.description: Walking is slower than running and faster than crawling.
tips.example: She prefers to walk rather than run to enjoy the scenery.

tips.description: Walking is often used to describe regular or habitual actions.
tips.example: He walks to wark every day.

tips.description: It often appears as:
tips.example:
- Walk in the park
- Walk the dog
- Walk home

tips.description: 'Walk in the park' is a phrase meaning something is easy, not always a literal walk.
tips.example: Math is a walk in the park for her.

cards.description: To move using your legs, at a slower pace than running
cards.example: Every morning, I walk my dog in the park.

tips.description: Sleep as a noun emphasizes its necessity, just like food or air.
tips.example: Humans can't survive without sleep, it's essential.

tips.description: Mentioning a lack of sleep suggests negative consequences for health and mood.
tips.example: Her lack of sleep made her irritable.

tips.description: It often appears as:
tips.example:
- Get some sleep
- Need sleep
- Lack of sleep

cards.description: The natural resting state in which your body is not active and your mind is unconscious
cards.example: I didn't get enough sleep last night.

tips.description: It often appears as:
tips.example:
- Look at that
- Look at me
- Look at it

cards.description: To direct your eyes towards something and pay attention to it
cards.example: Look at that bird in the tree.

tips.description: Commonly used in casual speech to ask for permission in friendly situations.
tips.example: let me try your new bicycle!

tips.description: Indicates the speaker is giving someone consent or the freedom to do something.
tips.example: You can let yourself have some fun.

tips.description: It often appears as:
tips.example:
- Let it go
- Let him in
- Let her know

cards.example: I let him borrow my car.

tips.description: Refers to leasing out property, often used when talking about real estate.
tips.example: They let their cottage during the summer months.

tips.description: It often appears as:
tips.example:
- Let for rent
- Let on lease
- Let for a year

cards.example: He lets out his apartment to tourists.

tips.description: Use add when mixing two things to make one, like ingredients in cooking
tips.example: Add the flour and eggs to make the batter

tips.description: When gradually putting something into another, use add to describe the action
tips.example: Slowly add sugar to the lemonade

tips.description: It often appears as:
tips.example:
- Add to
- Add together
- Add up

cards.description: To join or combine something with something else
cards.example: She added some milk to her coffee

cards.description: To increase the amount, number, or total of something
cards.example: He works a second job to add to his income

tips.description: Add is used when contributing to something to increase its worth or effect
tips.example: Good service will add to the restaurant's reputation

tips.description: Use add when you're talking about increasing numbers or quantities
tips.example: This sale will add to our overall profits

tips.description: It often appears as:
tips.example:
- Add value
- Add interest
- Add emphasis

cards.example: He added that the food was delicious

tips.description: Add is used to provide more details or extra information in aa conversation
tips.example: She added that the meeting is tomorrow at 9 am.

tips.description: When giving clarity or afterthoughts use add to introduce your point
tips.example: I forgot to add, the deadline is next Monday

tips.description: It often appears as:
tips.example:
- Add comment
- Add note
- Add thought
